Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Quantifying Climate-forced Extinction Risks for Lizards, Amphibians, Fishes, and Plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Climate change due to increases in anthropogenic carbon is altering global patterns of temperature and rainfall. These environmental changes are transforming plant communities, which in turn may be causing local extinctions of many vertebrate species. For example, when faced with prolonged heat waves and droughts, trees may be unable to draw sufficient water from the soil and drop most of their leaves. Diminished leaf cover allows more sunlight to reach the ground, amplifying local warming trends and increasing heat and water stress for plants themselves and for many vertebrate species. The goal of this award is to evaluate how climate-driven changes to plant communities are increasing extinction rates for certain "cold-blooded" vertebrate species (i.e., lizards, frogs). This study hypothesizes that many such vertebrate species are going extinct in part because rising temperatures are directly stressful to them, and in part because rising temperatures also damage plant communities, upon which animals rely for food, water, and shelter. Intensive studies will be made at specific localities on five continents where targeted animal species have recently gone extinct. At these sites, researchers with expertise in plant and animal physiology and ecology will collaborate to quantify the extent to which recent droughts and warm-spells have altered plant communities, which in turn have increased heat and water stress on animals. These local studies will then be linked (via remote sensing methods and online databases), to create a worldwide data set that integrate information on temperature, rainfall, plant die-offs, and the physiological limits of targeted animals to heat and water stress. Such data will enable scientists to predict and test, with unprecedented accuracy across regions and continents, how extinction rates among targeted vertebrate species relate to current and expected changes in rainfall, temperature, and plant communities.

Previous models of climate-warming impacts have focused on plants or animals, but not both. For example, many climate change scientists study animal systems in isolation of plant systems, thus emphasizing only the role of changing climate per se on animal taxa (e.g., rising temperatures limit lizards from foraging in direct sunlight). This project differs by a) modeling how climate-driven changes to plant communities increase warm spells and drought conditions, and b) showing how changes to plant communities alters the environment available used by the targeted animals species and push their physiological limits, speeding their extinction rates. This model will be grounded by field studies that test for non-climate related causes of animal extinctions; this will enable scientists to determine the factors that explain the ever increasing extinction rates among targeted animals. New web-based products will be developed that use remote sensing technology to predict current and future degradations in ecosystems across the globe. A project of this scope requires collaboration among scientists with expertise in climatology, physiology, biodiversity, and remote sensing. An international team from 20 countries will work together on this project; a new generation of postdoctoral research fellows and hundreds of graduate students will be trained in the latest physiological and mathematical methods in climate change studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major objectives of the Sites-Bauer studies included: (1) resolving phylogenetic relationships for selected groups of lizards throughout parts of the Americas, Africa, and Asia; and (2) to collect field thermal data (temperature preferences) for some species included in these phylogenies. Phylogenetic studies focused on lizard clades that included different reproductive modes (oviparity vs viviparity) and thermoregulatory strategies (heliotherms vs thermoconformers), which allowed for multiple replicated tests of the evolutionary origins of traits likely to elevate extinction risk.  Viviparous species are hypothesized to be at greater extinction risk due to climate warming than are oviparous taxa, as are tropical thermoconformers relative to temperate heliothermic species. The lizard families chosen for molecular phylogenetic study, in addition to those already published, were selected to include 30+ separate origns of viviparity (a conservative estimate across the 15+ families), and 8+ of 11 known family-level transitions from thermoconformers to helio- therms. Jointly our labs conducted extensive field work in parts of Africa, Asia, and the Americas, to sample missing taxa, collect sequence data to infer phylogenetic relationships for the target groups, time-calibrate these phylogenies, and reconstruct transitions in reproductive and thermo- regulatory modes for each clade (family).   

Aaron Bauer lab:  This research group included 7 MS students and 3 post-doctoral associates, and generated species level molecular phylogenies on selected taxa of African lacertids, skinks, and geckos (robust phylogenies exist for cordylids and gerrhosaurids).  Thermal data (preferred temperatures) were collected for selected taxa in these groups, with emphasis on the skink genus Trachylepis, which includes many viviparous species.  African field work centered on Angola, Namibia, South Africa, & Zambia. In tropical Asia similar studies centered on skinks, geckos, and agamids, with study sites in Thailand, India and Sarawak (Malaysian Borneo).  The gekkonid genus Cnemaspis was targeted for its inclusion of both diurnal and nocturnal taxa, and also forest-dwelling species of skinks and agamids that are assumed to be thermal conformers. Bauer's first post-doc (Dr. M. Metallinou) was killed in Zambia (by an elephant), but he mentored two subsequent post-docs from India.  One Angolan biologist, Susana Bandiera, conducted field work with. the Bauer group on several occasions, and is now in the process of applying to Villanoval University to begin a MS program in the Bauer lab.

Jack Sites lab: This lab included 4 BYU PhD students, 4 BYU undergraduates, one post-doc, as well as colleagues and graduate student visitors from Brazil (2 MS students & 1 research collaborator) & Argentina (2 PhD students & 2 research collaborators). Phylogenetic studies have focused intensively on the Corytophanidae, Gekkonidae (genus Homonota, a Phyllodactylus study is in progress), Liolaemidae, Teiidae, and Polychrotidae; earlier phylogenetic studies had been published for Anguidae, Gymnophthalmidae, Phrynosomatidae, & Xantusiidae; all of these preceded this award, but provide time calibrated genealogies that will benefit the comparative evolutionary transitions that are the focus of our comparative studies of vulnerability of lizards to climate-driven extinction risks.  Two PhD students developed thesis projects on New World clades: C, Aguilar focused phylogenetic/species delimitation studies on species of Liolaemus restricted to the far northern range of the genus (Peru, Bolivia, & northern Chile). He also lead two groups of Peruvian students to high-elevation sites in the northern Andes to collect ecophysiological data (August 2017) local species of Liolaemus (and frogs) at two localities; these trips were successful but hobos were stolen at the end of the second expedition. D, Tucker's thesis focused on: (1) a molecular phylogeny of the Teiidae (all genera); (2) a phylogeneticc study of the Caribbean endemic Pholidoscelis; and (3) a phylogeographic study of the teiid Ameiva ameiva, across the Amazon & Cerrado biomes.  PhD students L. Welton & P.L. Wood contributed similar studies of Old World geckos, agamics, & varanids from regions not sampled by the Bauer lab.  In combination, both labs contributed original data to major studies of a large fraction of the world's lizard families.
